description: Applying the mental model of Test-Driven Development (TDD) as an empirical engineering approach to master software design and manage complexity alongside Agentic AI tools.
name: This Mental Model Changed How I Design Software FOREVER
notes:
Test-Driven Development (TDD) functions as an empirical engineering approach and a vital mental model for software design, enabling engineers to manage complexity and break down problems efficiently, which is essential when working with Agentic AI tools. Mastering TDD allows humans to bring necessary engineering skills to the process, ensuring good designs are achieved faster, whereas a lack of a good design mental model means Agentic AI will likely help make a mess faster.

- **TDD as the Essential Mental Model for Software Design:** Test-Driven Development (TDD) provides a crucial mental model for approaching software design, enabling engineers to achieve better results and reduce cognitive load.
- **Human Engineering Skills Remain Paramount with Agentic AI:** In the age of Generative AI coding agents, what humans contribute is no longer typing but engineering skills, making a good design mental model like TDD more important than ever.
- **TDD as an Empirical Engineering Approach:** TDD functions as an empirical engineering approach to software design, focusing on iteration and continuous learning about the problem and the medium.
- **Managing Complexity is the Core Job:** A fundamental job of a software engineer is to manage complexity in software by finding good abstractions, modularizing code, and separating concerns. TDD facilitates this by forcing focus and breaking down problems into smaller, manageable chunks.
- **The Risk of Agentic AI Without Good Design Skills:** Lacking a good mental model for software design means Agentic AI tools will likely only help create a complex mess faster, leading to difficulty managing complexity and failure to produce modular, loosely coupled code.
- **The Iterative Process with Agentic AI:** The recommended process involves starting with user needs, breaking the problem into chunks, specifying behavior and coding standards for one chunk, having the AI write the code, improving the design, and iterating on the next chunk.
- **Importance of Acceptance Tests and Specifications:** Working with AI tools is enhanced by using automated acceptance tests to specify required functionality in detail, providing clear constraints and guards against regression.
- **Guiding AI with Principles:** It is helpful to include clear code principles in prompts, such as preferring simple, clean, and maintainable solutions, prioritizing readability, using small functions, and following the Single Responsibility Principle, to ensure the AI generates reasonably good designs.
- **AI for Design Improvement vs. Refactoring:** If the AI's initial design needs improvement, engineers can ask the Generative AI tool to try again and create a new design that fits the constraints, but this is distinct from deterministic refactoring, which often still requires a dedicated tool or manual work in an IDE.
- **Context Window Optimization:** A new consideration when working with Agentic AI is optimizing the tool's context window as a first-order concern, though this is closely related to the TDD process of managing complexity and focusing on one aspect of design at a time.
resource: This Mental Model Changed How I Design Software FOREVER - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=U6PM8WehhJg

description: A talk exploring best practices and practical tips for leveraging AI tools and Large Language Models (LLMs) to achieve great results in software development through the "vibe coding" approach.
name: How To Get The Most Out Of Vibe Coding | Startup School
notes:
Achieving great results with **AI tools and Large Language Models (LLMs)** in "vibe coding" demands a strategic approach where developers **treat AI as a new programming paradigm**, meticulously **provide context and detailed instructions**, and **integrate professional software engineering best practices** like planning, testing, and version control to guide and refine AI-generated code.

- **Treat AI as a new programming language**, providing detailed context and information for good results.
- **Prioritize planning** with pure LLMs to define scope and architecture before coding, creating a comprehensive markdown plan.
- Implement projects **section by section**, checking progress, running tests, and **committing frequently** to version control.
- **Use Git religiously**, resetting to a clean state after failed attempts to prevent accumulation of bad code.
- **Write high-level integration tests** to catch regressions and unnecessary changes by LLMs.
- Leverage LLMs for **non-coding tasks** like DevOps and design work.
- For debugging, **copy-paste error messages** directly to the LLM, and for complex bugs, ask the AI to brainstorm solutions before writing code, always resetting after failed attempts.
- **Experiment with different AI models** as their strengths vary (e.g., planning, implementing, debugging).
- **Provide extensive, detailed instructions** to your AI coding agents.
- **Download and provide local documentation** to LLMs for better accuracy.
- Use LLMs as a **teacher** to explain code line-by-line for learning.
- Favor **modular architecture and small files** to improve AI comprehension and maintainability.
- Consider that **AI performance varies by tech stack** due to training data availability (e.g., Ruby on Rails performs well).
- Utilize **screenshots for design and bug demonstration** and **voice input** for faster interaction.
- **Refactor frequently** once code is working and tested, using LLMs to identify areas for improvement.
resource: How To Get The Most Out Of Vibe Coding | Startup School - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BJjsfNO5JTo

description: This talk reframes modern cloud application lock-in as switching costs, explaining how to manage them through architecture trade-offs, increasing developer velocity, and focusing on design intent rather than just service selection
name: AWS re:Invent 2023 - Do modern cloud applications lock you in?
notes:
The most important lesson conveyed is that perceived cloud "lock-in" should be reframed as manageable **switching costs**, which are most effectively reduced by focusing on core engineering disciplines like increasing organizational **velocity** and maintaining clear **software design intent** and meaningful **architecture decisions**, rather than solely relying on simple service mapping or abstraction layers. The ultimate takeaway is that having development discipline, expressing design intent, high velocity, and good automation mean switching costs won't be your biggest problem; capturing market opportunity will be.

Here are the most important points of the presentation:
- Modern cloud applications are defined by their effective utilization of cloud capabilities, being fine-grained, loosely coupled, often event-driven, and offering benefits like resilience, scalability, transparency, agility, and observability.
- The perceived "lock-in" of modern cloud applications should be reframed not as being literally locked up, but as **manageable switching costs** – a financial consideration involving effort, time, and money to move from one solution to another.
- Lock-in/switching costs are **multidimensional**, including vendor lock-in, but also switching costs related to product versions, skillsets, and even **mental lock-in**. Architecture is about seeing these multiple dimensions and making **trade-offs**, not a simple good vs. evil scenario.
- A powerful architectural maneuver is to break down problems into more dimensions (like using a two-dimensional matrix comparing **utility vs. switching cost**) and broadening the solution space.
- **Solving problems where they originate** is crucial; trying to solve application development problems like portability solely at the infrastructure level after the fact is ineffective.
- Simple approaches to managing switching costs often **don't work well**:
    - **Service mapping** across clouds fails because clouds are not carbon copies and their services have fundamental, non-matching details and integrations.
    - Basic **abstraction layers** (the "grim wrapper") are also ineffective for fine-grained distributed systems because logical layers cannot abstract **physical properties** such as pricing models, quotas, scalability limits, error handling, and service availability across different platforms.
- The **option to move** your workload is mathematically valuable but comes at a **cost**, including effort, complexity (which is very hard to undo), and crucially, **opportunity cost** (what else your developers could have been building).
- Wanting all options all the time ("Gregor's law") leads to drowning in complexity. The goal is not to eliminate switching costs entirely (like an option with a zero strike price or zero-deductible insurance) but to **minimize the _total_ cost** (investment now + future liability).
- Organizations aiming for agility should make decisions assuming today's dollars (investment now) are more expensive than future dollars (potential switching cost liability), prioritizing current investment in productivity and market opportunity.
- **Productivity comes before portability**. If you're not productive, the question of portability likely becomes irrelevant because your business may not succeed. Open source is great but often undersells itself by leading with portability rather than community, openness, and productivity benefits.
- There are effective approaches to manage switching costs:
    - Using **managed open source services**, which offer utility while keeping switching costs in check.
    - Significantly increasing **your own organizational velocity**. High velocity through automation, reduced friction, and smaller iterations dramatically reduces switching costs, potentially by orders of magnitude, regardless of the technology used. Velocity is a powerful dial within your control.
    - Maintaining clear **software design intent** and focusing on architecture as the sequence of meaningful decisions, rather than just service selection. Expressing intent using patterns and decisions (like in the Scatter-Gather example) prevents **mental lock-in** to one platform's way of thinking and provides a better starting point if you need to switch.
- Ultimately, if you have **development discipline**, express design intent with patterns, have high velocity, and good automation, the switching cost isn't going to be your biggest problem; **capturing market opportunity and maintaining velocity** will be the critical focus.
resource: AWS re:Invent 2023 - Do modern cloud applications lock you in? - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jykSBmnAM2I

description: This talk by Steve Yegge exploring the inevitable transformation of software engineering due to AI and LLMs, detailing changing developer roles and the increasing importance of testing and validation
name: Stop Writing Code – That’s what LLMs are for
notes:
**AI and LLMs are fundamentally transforming the role of software engineers**, shifting it from direct code writing to managing AI tools and necessitating a **five to ten times greater rigor in testing and validation** due to the non-deterministic nature and "hallucinations" of AI-generated code. This inevitable change means developers must adapt by focusing on higher-level architectural tasks and ensuring the quality and correctness of AI-produced output, with practices like Test-Driven Development becoming crucial.

- **AI and LLMs are fundamentally transforming software engineering**, making direct code writing less common.
- The developer role is shifting from a "cook" to a **"head chef" managing fleets of AI agents**, focusing on higher-level architectural tasks and orchestration.
- There's an **inevitable and urgent need for 5 to 10 times more rigorous testing and validation** due to AI hallucinations and the non-deterministic nature of AI-generated code.
- **Test-Driven Development (TDD) becomes crucial**, with LLMs even helping to write tests.
- The **path for junior developers is changing**, moving them towards more architectural roles and learning to manage agents, rather than focusing on low-level coding.
- Companies that **drag their feet on AI adoption are in serious trouble** and are "doomed."
- Engineers must **learn to deal with ambiguity and "noisy data"** from LLMs and develop an "instinct" for quality.
- Human "taste" and **creativity remain essential**, as AI currently lacks these qualities, allowing engineers to focus on innovative solutions.
- The change is **inevitable within the next 18 months to two years**, and it will not revert to previous methods.
resource: Stop Writing Code – That’s what LLMs are for - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yUv1xK9KOtE

description: Para GitHub, una base de datos de recursos sería un sistema fundamental para el seguimiento, monitoreo y optimización meticulosa de todos los activos de infraestructura, cómputo y operativos, con el fin de garantizar la escalabilidad continua, disponibilidad y eficiencia de costes de su plataforma global.
name: Invertir en el futuro sin romper el presente: el arte de priorizar en un mundo competitivo
notes:
Lo más importante de esta charla es cómo dominar la **priorización estratégica, la planificación y la construcción sostenible** para una plataforma a escala global como GitHub. Esto implica equilibrar eficazmente la necesidad constante de **innovación y velocidad** con los compromisos críticos de **disponibilidad de la plataforma, seguridad y una excelente experiencia para el desarrollador**, mientras se gestiona la deuda técnica y se prepara para el crecimiento futuro.

Lo más importante que alguien debería recordar de esta charla es el arte de la **priorización estratégica y la construcción sostenible** de una plataforma a escala global como GitHub, equilibrando constantemente la **innovación y la velocidad** con la **disponibilidad, la seguridad y la experiencia del desarrollador**. La autora comparte las prácticas que les funcionan en GitHub para mantener este equilibrio, especialmente en un entorno donde todo es "para ayer" y se construye sobre una plataforma con muchos años de historia.
Los puntos y prácticas más importantes que la autora intenta transmitir son:
- **Principios Fundamentales:**
    - La **disponibilidad y la seguridad son el trabajo número uno** ("job number one"). Es crucial construir una plataforma en la que la gente pueda confiar, ya que un producto innovador no sirve si no está disponible o no es seguro.
    - **La experiencia de los desarrolladores y la deuda técnica importan**. Ignorar estas áreas puede llevar a la frustración y la fuga de talento de los ingenieros.
    - **Competir para ganar:** GitHub busca la innovación, la disrupción del mercado, atraer usuarios, generar ingresos e influenciar la forma en que se construye el código, a pesar de ser el hogar del código abierto.
- **Gestión Proactiva y Reactiva (El "arte de priorizar"):**
    - **Gestión de Incidentes (Reactiva):** Tener ingenieros de guardia 24/7 y un rol "shield" para incidencias menos urgentes. Realizar **"post-mortems"** obligatorios con **objetivos de tiempo estrictos para remediar los problemas**, lo que a la larga acelera el proceso y evita la repetición del mismo incidente.
    - **Vulnerabilidades de Seguridad (Reactiva/Proactiva):** Las vulnerabilidades explotables tienen **prioridad cero**. Existe un equipo separado para **revisiones de seguridad** que analiza el código y la arquitectura de forma proactiva para prevenir problemas futuros y ahorrar trabajo de remediación.
    - **Presupuestos de Error (Error Budgets) y SLOs (Proactiva):** En lugar de solo medir la disponibilidad mensual, se mide la rapidez con la que se "quema" el presupuesto de error permitido. Cuando se alcanza un umbral, se frena el desarrollo de nuevas características para priorizar la estabilidad, lo que permite un manejo proactivo del riesgo y un balance de prioridades.
    - **"Good to Grow" (Proactiva):** Planificar y **prepararse para un crecimiento repentino e inesperado** de usuarios o carga. Se asume una capacidad para soportar **10x de crecimiento probado y 100x de crecimiento estimado**. Esto implica monitorear métricas directas (p.ej., número de solicitudes API) e indirectas (p.ej., tamaño de la base de datos) y hacer un uso responsable de los recursos de infraestructura ("Resource economy").
    - **Iniciativas de Ingeniería (Engineering Initiatives) (Proactiva):** Dedicar un porcentaje fijo de capacidad (20-30% no negociable) cada trimestre para que los ingenieros aborden directamente la **deuda técnica, prueben nuevas herramientas o simplifiquen funcionalidades** que afectan su velocidad o frustración en el día a día. Este es un rol rotatorio y voluntario donde los ingenieros proponen y votan ideas.
    - **Gestión de la Deuda Técnica (Proactiva):** Ver la deuda técnica como una **decisión consciente y controlada para aprovechar una oportunidad** (similar a una hipoteca). La clave es pagarla cuando comienza a interponerse en el camino y ralentizar el progreso. Se recomienda **incluir el coste de la refactorización** o de trabajar con un componente sano dentro de las estimaciones de desarrollo de nuevas funcionalidades para que el coste sea compartido con el equipo de producto.
    - **"Ship to Learn" y "Fail Fast" (Proactiva):** Desarrollar prototipos interactivos (mocks) y **obtener feedback de los clientes antes de construir funcionalidades**, reduciendo costos y evitando desarrollar algo que el cliente no necesita. Sin embargo, se reconoce que en algunos casos (p.ej., productos de IA con resultados no deterministas) puede ser necesario construir primero y mejorar después.
    - **Balance entre Innovación y Ganancia de Dinero (Proactiva):** Es fundamental balancear la construcción de funcionalidades innovadoras con las **funcionalidades solicitadas por los clientes que aseguran la retención y expansión del negocio**. Hay que destinar una capacidad reservada para estas últimas para generar ingresos y mantener a los clientes existentes.
- **Proceso de Planificación y Priorización:**
    - **Preparación con Datos:** Acudir a las reuniones de planificación con datos claros sobre el "cómo, qué y por qué" de cada iniciativa, incluyendo el número de clientes que la solicitaron, la oportunidad de mercado o los ingresos recurrentes anuales que generaría.
    - **Entender la Capacidad:** Calcular la capacidad real del equipo considerando vacaciones, guardias y un "buffer" para imprevistos.
    - **"Hunger Games" (La Reunión de Priorización):** En esta reunión entre líderes de producto e ingeniería, se decide qué priorizar en el trimestre, con la regla de que entre el **20% y el 30% de la capacidad se dedica a tareas que no son desarrollo de nuevas características** (disponibilidad, iniciativas de ingeniería).
    - **Transparencia:** El resultado es una lista clara de lo que se hará y lo que no, con explicaciones y riesgos documentados, que se comunica a todo el mundo. Esto fomenta la energía y motivación de los ingenieros, ya que saben que el plan es el mejor posible y sostenible.
    - **Flexibilidad ante el "Martillo":** En ocasiones, ante problemas críticos de infraestructura o apuestas estratégicas de la empresa (como en la IA), se puede "sacar el martillo" y detener todo lo demás para atacar un problema central, incluso si no agrada a los ingenieros, porque la necesidad y el valor son claros.

description: This talk offers a critical look at why the analytical data world is "the land DevOps forgot," and presents Data Mesh as a paradigm shift to enable decentralized, autonomous data operations, emphasizing that successful adoption requires significant organizational and cultural change.
name: Data - The Land DevOps Forgot
notes:
The most important lesson conveyed by this presentation is that the **data world operates under fundamentally different dynamics than operational systems, plagued by slow processes, fear of change, and escalating costs**, akin to "the land DevOps forgot". The paradigm shift offered by **Data Mesh**, which applies microservices principles to data, is the proposed solution; however, its successful implementation hinges crucially on **profound organizational and cultural change management, decentralized ownership, effective incentives, and overcoming a lack of interoperability between vendor platforms**, rather than just technical solutions.

Key points of the presentation:
- The data world, particularly **analytical data and ETL**, operates very differently from the operational world, often being "the land DevOps forgot."
- In the data world, **units of work take hours to days**, deployments are slow, and the lag from commit to seeing results can be several days, leading to **fear of change**, accumulated **technical debt**, and **increasing costs**.
- There's a significant **chasm in tech stacks and languages** between operational (e.g., Flutter, Closure) and analytical (e.g., Python, Scala, Spark) systems, leading to fragmentation and inconsistent results.
- Traditional Big Data approaches often result in inflexible, high-cost environments that **hold back business growth**.
- The solution is **Data Mesh**, a new paradigm akin to **microservices for data**, aiming to enable teams to move at their own pace with autonomous, independent deployments.
- **Key principles of Data Mesh** are: **domain ownership** of data, treating **data as a product**, providing a **self-service data platform**, and implementing **federated governance**.
- **Decentralizing data ownership** is challenging but crucial; it involves mapping organizational domains to data sets and making data owners accountable for their data product's operations, leading to reduced breakage.
- Establishing **clear boundaries** between internal and public data by introducing "private" and "public" flags, with eventual enforcement, is necessary to manage dependencies.
- Treating **data as a product** means ensuring it is discoverable, understandable (via schema, documentation), and trustworthy (via **lineage**, SLOs, and **quality rules**).
- A **self-service data platform** provides tools, visibility, and automated guardrails, empowering data product owners while managing cognitive load, and must be **user-centric** (supporting various languages like SQL and Python).
- **Incentives** are critical; while data owners take on support and production costs, mechanisms like **internal transfer pricing** (a marketplace where consumers pay for data products) can encourage high-quality data production.
- Major barriers to Data Mesh adoption include a **lack of interoperability** between vendor-specific data platforms and the **absence of an open, standardized definition for a data product** (like Swagger for APIs).
- Implementing Data Mesh requires an **incremental approach**, combining architectural changes with significant **organizational and cultural change management**.
- **Relentless communication** of "why" the change is needed, integrating into **planning cycles (e.g., OKRs)**, and building **support from all organizational levels** (top-down, bottom-up, middle-out) are essential.
- It's important to **ensure inclusion for all team members** during transitions, avoiding "Legacy land" vs. "Promised Land" divisions, and to **leave slack** in schedules to allow for innovation and change.
- Be **wary of vendor capture**; many vendors marketing "data mesh" may not offer true decentralized, independently operating solutions.
resource: Data - The Land DevOps Forgot - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=459-H33is6o

description: NDC London 2016. A great talk. I already recommended a previous version of this talk. It is a must. Thanks, @Fortiz2305 for reminding me of this talk.
name: Beyond_Features
notes:
The core message challenges the software industry's prevailing obsession with features and predictability, advocating for a paradigm shift to "software surgery" where the ultimate goal is to sustainably achieve business impact with minimal intervention, prioritizing discovery and continuous improvement as equally vital forms of work alongside feature delivery. This approach emphasizes curing problems and delivering results, even if it means no software at all, rather than merely cutting code or following rigid plans.
- **Shift from Feature Obsession**: The software industry often obsesses over delivering features and maintaining predictability, rather than focusing on actual business impact.
- **Agile's Misinterpretation**: While the Agile Manifesto emphasized individuals and interactions, working software, customer collaboration, and adapting to change, current practices often prioritize processes, tools, detailed plans (backlogs as Gantt charts), and contract-like commitments (sprint commitments, velocity).
- **Predictability as Primary Optimization**: Agile methods, developed in the 1990s, historically optimized for predictability to counter the long, unpredictable nature of traditional projects. Shorter batch sizes (sprints) were introduced to build confidence and make delivery more foreseeable.
- **Flawed Civil Engineering Metaphor**: Software development inappropriately adopted metaphors and practices from civil engineering (architects, builds, quantity surveyors, front-loading risk), which are suited for static, large-scale construction rather than adaptive software.
- **New Metaphor: Software Surgery**:
    - **Goal**: Sustainably minimize lead time to **business impact (results)**, even if it means delivering no software at all.
    - **User Desire**: People seek to resolve problems (e.g., be well, have an itch scratched), not necessarily to undergo surgery or build a solution.
    - **Minimal Intervention**: Aim for the smallest possible intervention to achieve the desired outcome (like keyhole surgery).
    - **Professional Competence**: Professionals should use proven techniques, be prepared for unexpected issues, and prioritize curing the underlying problem.
    - **Beyond Cutting**: Software work, like surgery, involves significant study, theory, and practice to understand _what_ to do and _where_ to act, not just the act of coding. The "first rule of surgery is don't cut" applies to software: seek non-software solutions first.
- **Three First-Class Types of Work**: All three are essential and should be planned, tracked, measured, and celebrated.
    1. **Features**: The observable capabilities a computer provides. (Often the only thing measured, leading to skewed perceptions of progress).
    2. **Discovery**: Experimenting, exploring, and reducing uncertainty to identify the right problems or the most effective solutions. It involves learning and surfacing unknowns.
    3. **Kaizen (Systems Thinking)**: Continuous, small-scale improvements to the _system of work_ itself (e.g., learning, automation, process changes, relationship building). The goal is to make the work system more effective.
- **Rethink Engagement and Professionalism**:
    - **Business Stakeholders**: Re-engage by focusing on delivering tangible business impact and acting as consultants to diagnose needs, rather than merely executing feature requests.
    - **Management**: Recognize and support all three types of work (features, discovery, Kaizen) for accurate capacity planning and visibility.
    - **Software Professionals**: Cultivate a mindset of continuous learning, specializing in areas, and developing broader skills like influencing and negotiating, which are crucial for true professionalism beyond just coding.
    - **Software as a Tool**: Software is a means to an end (business impact), not the end itself. The ultimate objective is "curing," not merely "cutting code."
resource: Beyond_Features - https://vimeo.com/159502637

description: This presentation challenges the idea of blindly following software development practices like SOLID and Scrum, urging a re-evaluation of their continued relevance in light of changing contexts and technology, advocating for a more fluid, context-driven approach that prioritizes outcomes, learning, and continuous improvement
name: The Most Dangerous Phrase: SOLID, Scrum And Other Antiques
notes:
The presentation discusses why people and organizations cling to outdated practices, using SOLID principles and Scrum as examples, and how to evaluate whether a practice is still useful over time. Here are the most important points:
- **Habit and "We've Always Done it That Way":** The primary reason people and organizations continue with existing practices is habit. The phrase "we've always done it that way" is a dangerous one that prevents critical thinking and change.
- **The Problem with "Obvious" Practices:** Many practices are followed because they are considered obviously right, based on received wisdom or how people were taught, without considering whether they still make sense.
- **The Four Questions to Evaluate Technology**: Drawing on the work of Eli Goldratt, the presenter introduces four questions that should be asked when adopting new technology: what is the power of the technology, what limitation does it diminish, what rules enabled us to manage this limitation, and what new rules do we need to introduce to exploit it. These questions can be applied not only to technology but to practices.
- **The Need to Re-evaluate Practices Over Time:** Practices should be re-evaluated over time to see if they are still valid. The key questions here are: what has changed since we adopted it, how has the limitation changed over time, and what should we be doing instead.
- **Context is Crucial:** Understanding the context in which a practice was developed is crucial. This involves talking to "old people" who were there at the time to build up a profile of what was going on, and understanding that there are multiple perspectives.
- **SOLID Principles as an Example of Outdated Advice:** The presenter argues that the SOLID principles, which were relevant when development teams were more siloed, are less relevant now that teams are cross-functional. The single responsibility principle (SRP), for example, suggests separating code based on who is working on it (e.g., DBA vs. accountant), rather than keeping code that changes together in the same place. The presenter suggests that code should be kept together while it fits in a programmer's head, and separated only when it becomes too complex.
- **Separation of Concerns:** The idea of "separation of concerns" is often misunderstood as a way to arrange code (like layered architecture) but was originally conceived as separating concerns such as correctness and efficiency, and involves considering multiple concerns simultaneously.
- **Scrum's Origins and Limitations:** Scrum emerged in the early 90s to address the problem of slow, large projects, with the idea of shorter sprints and more frequent feedback. While it was revolutionary for its time, it is now optimized for problems that no longer exist, because of advancements in technology.
- **Technology Changes:** Since the introduction of Scrum, the technology landscape has changed dramatically, with faster languages, continuous delivery, and cloud-based provisioning, enabling much faster iteration and deployment cycles.
- **Scrum can Hinder Fast Flow:** Scrum is optimized for moving from years to months and weeks, but now, the pace of software development has moved to minutes. As a result, sticking to scrum can mean that competitors are able to move faster.
- **Alternative Planning Cadences:** The presenter suggests two planning cadences: quarterly planning with OKRs and immediate changes when needed. This includes doing a "big room planning" to let teams self-select into work.
- **Dynamic Teams:** Teams should be fluid, changing as needed based on demand, instead of being fixed and having to work around limitations. The focus should be on bringing people to the work, rather than making the work fit the team.
- **Separate Deployment from Release:** Deployment should be a technical decision, and releases a commercial one. Deployment can be done continuously, and releases can be timed to fit business needs.
- **Daily Steering:** Daily steering should be about what is left to do, not about what has already been done. It should be forward-looking, focusing on progress and new learnings.
- **Structural Inertia and Cognitive Biases:** The persistence of outdated practices is due to structural inertia and cognitive biases such as commitment bias and consistency bias.
- **Bounded vs. Centered Communities:** Bounded communities are defined by rigid rules (like certifications) and struggle to adapt, whereas centered communities are defined by values that are constantly being communicated. Centered communities are more resilient because people are either closer or further from a set of values, but never outside of the community.
- **Think For Yourself:** It's essential to think for yourself, look past dogma, challenge the status quo, and assess your own tools and practices. Talk to old people, but remember that they have different perspectives, and no single source should be believed without further investigation.
- **The Most Dangerous Phrase:** The most dangerous phrase is "we've always done it that way".
The talk argues for a critical approach to practices and encourages revisiting them in light of changing contexts and technology. The presenter advocates for a more fluid, context-driven approach to software development, and emphasizes the importance of focusing on outcomes, learning, and continuous improvement.
resource: The Most Dangerous Phrase: SOLID, Scrum And Other Antiques - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L2dh1bqrLC4

description: Very interesting talk to be aware of our aversion to uncertainty. We usualy make bad decisions in order to avoid the feeling of uncertainty.
name: Embracing Uncertainty
notes:
Humans are fundamentally uncomfortable with uncertainty, often preferring to be demonstrably wrong rather than admitting ignorance, which leads to rigid processes and an illusion of control. The essential lesson is to **embrace this inherent uncertainty** by expecting the unexpected, actively reducing ignorance through deliberate discovery, and using approaches like real options to defer commitments until more information is available.

- Humans are hardwired to be uncomfortable with uncertainty, often preferring to be demonstrably wrong rather than admitting ignorance.
- This discomfort leads to the creation of rigid processes, rules, and hierarchies, which provide an illusion of certainty and control, but can cause suffering and inefficiency (e.g., overly detailed planning, large backlogs).
- Traditional risk management often focuses on minimizing the _likelihood_ of bad events, mistakenly believing it can be reduced to zero, rather than preparing for and managing their _impact_.
- The original spirit of Agile (valuing individuals, working software, customer collaboration, responding to change) has often been lost, replaced by an obsession with rigid methodologies, tools, documentation, and early commitments.
- **Embracing uncertainty** is a fundamental pattern for effective delivery.
- Key practices to embrace uncertainty include:
    - **Rolling wave planning:** Focus on near-term priorities and continuously breaking down work, keeping backlogs small and fluid.
    - **Spike and stabilize (concurrent set-based engineering):** Experiment with multiple solutions early and defer commitment to a single one until more is known.
    - **Theory of Constraints:** Optimize for overall system throughput rather than local effort or utilization, recognizing the need for slack.
    - **Generalizing specialists:** Foster cross-functional teams where individuals wear multiple hats and contribute broadly to team goals.
    - **Real options:** View decisions as options with value that changes over time and expires. **Commit deliberately, not early**, waiting for more information.
    - **Deliberate discovery:** Actively seek out "unknown unknowns" by assuming that "some unexpected bad things will happen," and proactively working to reduce second-order ignorance.
    - **Double loop learning:** Beyond adapting current processes (single loop), critically examine and improve the learning process itself.
- Cognitive biases like attribution bias, confirmation bias, and bias bias make it difficult to acknowledge and embrace uncertainty, as they reinforce self-serving beliefs and resistance to uncomfortable truths.
- Uncertainty is inevitable; the only certainty is uncertainty itself. Expect the unexpected and even the unexpectable.
resource: Embracing Uncertainty - http://vimeo.com/43603453

description: Very good talk about the "Agile" mindset (aka experimentation or growth mindset)
name: The Power of an Agile Mindset
notes:
Drawing on the YouTube source [NEW YOUTUBE SOURCE], here are some of the most important points of Linda Rising's presentation on the agile mindset:
- **There are two fundamental attitudes towards intelligence and talent: fixed and growth (or agile) mindsets**.
    - A **fixed mindset** believes that intelligence and talent are basic, unchangeable traits you are born with. People with this mindset think you either have it or you don't.
    - A **growth (or agile) mindset** believes that intelligence and talent can be developed and improved through effort, learning, and hard work.
- **Research demonstrates the impact of these mindsets.** Linda Rising discusses an experiment with grade school children who were given an easy test. Afterward, they were randomly assigned to a "fixed" or "growth" mindset group based on what the researchers told them about their performance.
    - Children in the **fixed mindset** group were told, "You did very well, you must be smart".
    - Children in the **growth mindset** group were told, "You did very well, you must have worked hard".
- **These seemingly small manipulations had significant and statistically significant effects**.
    - When offered a harder test, the **growth mindset** group almost all wanted to take it to learn, while the **fixed mindset** group preferred an easy test where they would continue to look good.
    - During the difficult test, **growth mindset** students focused on strategies and seeking help, while **fixed mindset** students expressed feelings of inadequacy.
    - When given the option to see exams of those who did better or worse, **growth mindset** students wanted to see the better exams to learn, whereas **fixed mindset** students wanted to see the worse exams to feel better about themselves.
    - On a subsequent easy test, the scores of **growth mindset** students improved, while the scores of **fixed mindset** students dropped.
    - In letters to future students, **growth mindset** students offered advice and encouragement, while **fixed mindset** students were discouraging and some even inflated their scores.
- **The goal for someone with a fixed mindset is to look good and avoid challenges where they might not succeed**. Failure is seen as an indication of a lack of inherent ability. Effort is viewed as something only those who lack talent need to exert. They may become helpless when facing challenges.
- **The goal for someone with an agile (growth) mindset is to get better, learn, and grow**. Challenges are embraced as opportunities for improvement. Failure is seen as feedback and a chance to learn. Effort is recognized as the path to mastery. They demonstrate resilience when faced with setbacks.
- **This concept extends beyond individuals to companies.** Enron, with its "smartest guys in the room" mentality and "rank and yank" system, exemplified a fixed mindset, leading to deceptive behavior and ultimately the company's downfall. Southwest Airlines, on the other hand, with its focus on hiring for attitude ("Southwest Spirit") and valuing people and growth, embodies an agile mindset.
- **Managers' mindsets significantly impact their teams.** Managers with a fixed mindset tend to make quick judgments about individuals' abilities and treat them accordingly, which can influence their performance.
- **It is possible to shift from a fixed mindset to a growth mindset.** This involves focusing on effort, strategies, and learning from failure. It's important to avoid labeling individuals based on perceived talent or ability.
- **Practical advice for cultivating a growth mindset includes:**
    - Talking about effort and hard work.
    - Discussing failure as a form of feedback.
    - Avoiding labels that imply fixed abilities.
    - Emphasizing growth and practice.
    - Saying "**I'm not good at this yet**" instead of "I'm not good at this".
- **Agile methodologies align with a growth mindset, emphasizing continuous improvement, embracing failure as a learning opportunity, and adapting to change**. If an agile company is doing the same thing year after year, it is not truly agile; growth and change are essential.
- Overcoming the tendency towards a fixed mindset often requires conscious effort and recognizing that our brains may try to take the "lazy" or familiar path. Taking small steps and acknowledging that change takes time are important.
resource: The Power of an Agile Mindset - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pQeohrdhvYU

description: This talk explores Software Design as the core of development, illustrating how test-driven development (TDD) serves as a critical design tool for achieving modularity, cohesion, and continuous structural improvement.
name: You ONLY Get Code LIKE THIS With TDD
notes:
**Test-driven development (TDD)** serves as a primary **approach to software design** that utilizes rapid feedback loops to naturally produce high-quality code attributes such as **modularity, cohesion, and separation of concerns**. By writing tests first, developers can work in **small, incremental steps** and gain the confidence to safely **refactor and evolve** their designs while ensuring the intended behavior remains intact.

- **Incremental Progress:** TDD organizes work into extremely small, manageable steps, providing a clear path forward even when tasks are complex.
- **Rapid Feedback:** The cycle of writing a test and seeing it fail as predicted offers immediate feedback and learning before any production code is written.
- **Software Design Tool:** TDD is primarily an approach to design that utilizes feedback to improve the quality and structure of the code.
- **Quality Side Effects:** Aiming for testable code naturally promotes essential quality markers such as modularity, cohesion, separation of concerns, abstraction, and minimal coupling.
- **Inherent Testability:** Writing tests before code ensures the resulting implementation is easy to test, avoiding the extra work of trying to test complex, existing code.
- **Safe Refactoring:** The suite of tests created through TDD allows developers to safely change the structure of the code (refactor) with the confidence that they are not altering its intended behavior.
- **Reduced Debugging:** Because tests are fine-grained and provide specific reasons for failure, the time spent manually debugging is significantly decreased.
- **Flow Maintenance:** A failing test acts as a perfect "bookmark," making it easy for a developer to pick up exactly where they left off after a break.
- **Reliability:** Simple automated tests generated during TDD can prevent the majority of critical production failures caused by common coding mistakes like off-by-one errors.
- **Creativity and Exploration:** Rather than limiting creativity, TDD acts as a tool—much like a ruler for a carpenter—to help developers explore the problem space and find better design answers.
- **Support for Continuous Integration:** The fast, automated feedback provided by TDD is a prerequisite for successful continuous integration and high-frequency delivery.
resource: You ONLY Get Code LIKE THIS With TDD - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aG6yhdQ9mLc

description: Simon Wardley introduces maps for strategic situational awareness, detailing how technological evolution, inertia, and the rise of AI impact decision-making and software architecture, emphasizing the challenge of deciding where humans maintain control
name: From here to there and back again
notes:
Understanding and mapping your competitive landscape is crucial for effective strategy, as everything evolves and past success often creates inertia to necessary change. The rise of AI makes architectural decision-making increasingly about **consciously deciding where humans must maintain control** in systems, given the machine's ability to act as the real architect and decision-maker.

- Strategy requires true situational awareness achieved through **maps**, which utilize an anchor (the user), position, and an evolutionary axis (Genesis to Commodity/Utility) to provide meaning to space.
- Maps help overcome organizational inertia and past narratives, allowing for useful challenges focused on the landscape rather than the person or their "story."
- There is **no one-size-fits-all approach**; project methodologies (like Agile or Six Sigma), financing, and contracting must be tailored to the specific evolutionary stage of the components being addressed.
- **Climactic Patterns** (economic rules like 'everything evolves,' 'past success breeds inertia,' and 'efficiency enables innovation') predict necessary changes and guide investment toward future needs and emerging practices, and away from inertia barriers.
- The industrialization of machine cognition (LLMs/AI) results in **conversational programming** (vibe coding), where the machine rapidly builds systems and often becomes the real architect and decision-maker.
- Architectural diagrams represent a belief of the system; the **real architecture is the code itself**, and the decisions are made by the entity creating that code.
- The primary challenge for future system architecture is making the **conscious decision** about **where humans must maintain control** and involvement (requiring software engineering) and where control can be abandoned to the machine for convenience.
resource: From here to there and back again - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hEjjCI3kTM4

description: This talk explores the pitfalls of technology anarchy and autocracy in platform engineering and advocates for escaping them by building opinionated platform capabilities with contextual technical alignment to accelerate delivery teams
name: Escaping A MAJOR Platform Engineering PITFALL
notes:
The most important lesson is that organizations don't need to trade off between technology **anarchy** (low alignment, high autonomy) and **autocracy** (high alignment, low autonomy), but should instead strive for **high alignment and high autonomy**. This is achieved by building **opinionated platform capabilities** with **contextual technical alignment** to dramatically accelerate delivery teams by providing paved roads and reducing unplanned work.

- Technology **anarchy** (low alignment, high autonomy) leads to significant unplanned work, high cognitive load, lack of economies of scale, difficulty sharing engineers, and painful organizational-wide changes for delivery teams.
- Technology **autocracy** (high alignment, low autonomy) enforced by strict rules and gatekeepers results in slow delivery and stifled innovation.
- Anarchy often arises as a counter-reaction to negative experiences with autocracy.
- The perception that alignment and autonomy must be traded off is false; organizations can achieve **high alignment and high autonomy**.
- The solution is to build **opinionated platform capabilities** that provide **contextual technical alignment** as "paved roads".
- Alignment should be provided through guidance and context from engineering leaders (tech stack, architecture, expectations, business consequences), not strict command and control rules.
- Opinionated platforms accelerate delivery teams by significantly reducing unplanned work and cognitive load by providing out-of-the-box solutions that embody this alignment.
- This approach facilitates consistency, easier knowledge sharing, and centralized handling of broad changes.
- Achieving this requires **higher investment in the platform team** (increased platform costs), which is a beneficial trade-off compared to the cost spread across many delivery teams.
resource: Escaping A MAJOR Platform Engineering PITFALL - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tu8qaKa0pKQ

description: Interesting conversation about high performance engineering organizations and how the pace of production is the heartbeat of the organization. They also discuss some very interesting ideas about how great teams generate great engineers, rather than the other way around.
name: Honeycomb's secret to high-performing teams
notes:
The most important lesson is that **high-performing engineering teams prioritize learning from production through observability, supported by a rapid CI/CD pipeline (ideally within 15 minutes), to foster a curious, collaborative, and ownership-driven engineering culture focused on solving meaningful problems rather than just firefighting bugs**. Someone should remember to **be curious in production and invest in observability and rapid deployment to create a virtuous feedback loop and empower engineers to continuously learn and improve their systems**.

Here are the most important points of the presentation, based on the provided transcript:
- **Observability is defined as learning from production, going beyond just metrics, logs, and traces.** It involves being curious and observing software in novel ways, then sharing these observations with the team.
- The mathematical definition of observability from control systems theory is understanding internal system state by looking from the outside. This is increasingly relevant for complex systems like those with microservices.
- **The key to observability is instrumenting code to ask any question and understand any internal system state without prior knowledge**. You should be able to slice and dice already gathered context instead of adding new code for every new observation.
- Instrumentation should include a wide range of information, including parameters, runtime environment details, and high cardinality dimensions like user IDs. The philosophy is to include anything that might be useful in the future.
- There's a divergence between monitoring tools focused on infrastructure health and observability tools focused on whether the code is working and the user experience. Observability shifts the perspective to the end-user journey.
- **A healthy CI/CD pipeline with rapid deployments (ideally within 15 minutes) is crucial for high-performing teams**. This creates a tight feedback loop and fosters a strong sense of ownership among engineers.
- Shipping code frequently and safely should be as regular as a heartbeat to deliver value to users.
- **Observability allows engineers to have a continuous "conversation" with their code in production**, often using an IDE alongside observability tools.
- Finding bugs is the hard part, and observability is well-positioned to help with this by speaking the language of endpoints and variables.
- **Being curious in production is essential** for understanding how software behaves at scale, as many interesting bugs only appear in production.
- High-performing teams spend most of their time solving new and interesting problems that push the business forward, rather than firefighting bugs.
- The environment and team culture are far more powerful than individual knowledge in determining an engineer's performance. Great teams make great engineers, not the other way around.
- Software development is a socio-technical problem, and the majority of a system's knowledge resides in the heads of the people who work on it.
- If you're frustrated with your engineering team's performance, **take a long hard look at your CI/CD pipeline and aim for 15 minutes or less, and invest in observability**.
resource: Honeycomb's secret to high-performing teams - https://changelog.com/shipit/11

description: Do you know what scalability really is? It's a mathematical function that's simple, precise, and useful. REALLY useful. It describes the relationship between system performance and load. In this talk you'll learn the function (the Universal Scalability Law), how it describes and predicts system behavior you see every day, and how to use it in practice. I'll show you how to understand the function, how to capture the data you need to measure your own system's behavior (you probably already have that), and how to analyze the data with the USL. You'll leave this talk knowing exactly what scalability is and what causes non-linear scaling. There are two factors, and you'll start seeing those everywhere, too. As a result, when systems don't scale you'll know what kind of problem to look for, and you'll avoid building bottlenecks into your systems in the first place. Final note: this talk requires zero mathematical skill.
name: LISA17 - Scalability Is Quantifiable: The Universal Scalability Law
resource: LISA17 - Scalability Is Quantifiable: The Universal Scalability Law - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lZU6RK0oazM

description: Great interview with great ideas (mocking-free testing, scalability of horizontal organization, FAST framework, code evolution with evolutionary design...). Very worthwhile.
name: Scaling Organizations and Design with James Shore
notes:
The most important lesson conveyed is that **software development benefits from embracing iterative and adaptive approaches across various aspects, from team scaling with fluid models like FAST to continuously evolving software design and considering different philosophies in testing**. Someone should remember the emphasis on **continuous improvement and adapting to change rather than adhering to rigid upfront plans**.
Here are the most important points of the presentation:
- **Scaling Organizations:**
    - James Shore contrasts **horizontal scaling (adding more autonomous teams)** with **vertical scaling using Fluid Scaling Technology (FAST), where more people work as a single, rapidly re-organizing team**.
    - Horizontal scaling, while beneficial for autonomy, can struggle with Conway's Law and adapting to changing business needs over time.
    - **FAST emphasizes fluidity with teams self-organizing every two days based on the work to be done**, allowing for flexible allocation of skills and potentially being a superior approach to horizontal scaling.
    - Concerns about the perceived chaos of FAST can be mitigated with proper change management and coaching, emphasizing that people are expected to stay on a task or team until they are no longer needed there.
- **Evolutionary Design:**
    - Evolutionary design, considered the most important idea in Agile, involves **incremental design (simplest design for today), reflective design (refactoring to enable new features), and continuous design (constant revision and improvement)**.
    - It is crucial for maintaining a low cost of change over time, which is fundamental for Agile to work effectively.
    - The principle of making the design "perfect for today" should be balanced with leaving the code "better than you found it," prompting ongoing small refactorings.
    - Refactoring should often occur _before_ adding a new feature (reflective design) to make the addition easier and improve the existing design.
- **Testing:**
    - There are two fundamental approaches to testing: **isolated interaction-based testing (often using mocks) and sociable state-based testing (testing without mocks)**.
    - **Isolated interaction-based testing** validates behavior by verifying communication between units but can lead to tests that don't reflect real system behavior.
    - **Sociable state-based testing** involves testing the system's observable state changes as it interacts with other parts of the system, offering more realism but potentially requiring modifications to production code to expose state.
    - "Testing without mocks" in James Shore's view is about this sociable state-based approach, where you might use "nullable infrastructure objects" or "embedded stubs" to manage external interactions in tests rather than isolating with traditional mocks.

description: A very interesting interview to Marty Cagan. Very good insights about empowered teams, product management, and team organization.
name: The nature of product
notes:
Here are the most important points from Marty Cagan's presentation:
- **The fundamental difference between feature teams and real product teams:** Feature teams are handed a roadmap of prioritized features (solutions) to build, primarily serving the business. In contrast, real product teams are given problems to solve (customer or company problems) and are empowered to come up with the best solutions. Real product teams focus on outcomes (solving problems) rather than output (releasing features).
- **The drastically different role of the product manager:** In feature teams, the product manager often acts as a project manager or "cat herder," gathering requirements and ensuring delivery. In empowered product teams, the product manager is responsible for discovering solutions that are valuable and viable, working as a peer with designers (focused on usability) and engineers (focused on feasibility). The job is so different that Cagan suggests they shouldn't even share the same title.
- **Misconceptions about product management:** Many people mistakenly believe that product managers primarily write requirements (PRDs, user stories) and hand them off to designers and engineers for implementation. They also often think the job is just about cranking out features based on a roadmap. Cagan emphasizes that product management in successful companies involves deep collaboration and bringing unique skills to the team beyond just defining what to build.
- **Don't overinvest in problem validation:** While understanding the problem is important, **people buy solutions, not the problem**. Product teams should be careful not to spend excessive time validating a problem, especially if it's already well-understood, and instead focus on discovering a winning solution.
- **The true purpose of user research:** User research is not just about confirming that users like a prototype. The primary goal is to find all the reasons why users _won't_ use the product. It's evaluative, helping to identify flaws and areas for improvement. Furthermore, **product managers and designers must actively participate in user research sessions**; reports alone are often ignored.
- **Transitioning from a feature team to a product team is possible:** Individuals in feature teams can try a small experiment, proposing to their manager that their team operate as a product team for a quarter or two, focusing on solving problems and measuring success by outcomes.
- **Key skills for a product manager in an empowered team:** A product manager needs to be an expert in four areas: understanding users and customers, being an expert in the data (product usage, analytics), understanding all parts of the business (marketing, sales, monetization, compliance), and knowing the competitive landscape and industry trends. They also need to ensure the team has strategic context (product vision and strategy) and learn product discovery skills and techniques.
- **Concerns about the evolution of product management:** Cagan is worried about the proliferation of unqualified "product people," particularly in Europe with the misapplication of the "product owner" role by agile coaches lacking product experience. He also sees issues with poorly implemented product ops that might interfere with the core responsibilities of a product manager.
- **The three sacred responsibilities of a product manager:** These must never be delegated: **unencumbered access to users and customers, unencumbered access to engineers, and unencumbered access to stakeholders**. Companies that try to split the product manager role by limiting these accesses create significant damage.
- **The danger of scaling with process over leaders:** While scaling is challenging, relying too heavily on processes (like SAFe) instead of developing strong leaders is a significant risk and can lead to "repackaged waterfall" that is the antithesis of agile principles. Cagan echoes Steve Jobs' warning about the "disease of process people".
- **Marty Cagan welcomes hard questions:** He finds them inspiring for his writing and encourages people to email him with challenging product management questions they can't find good answers to. His resources can be found at svpg.com.
resource: The nature of product - https://www.lennysnewsletter.com/p/the-nature-of-product-marty-cagan

description: Pure wisdom on why working in small, safe steps is the most efficient way to work in software product development when we have environments of high uncertainty (which is almost always).
name: GeePaw Hill on Incremental Software Delivery
notes:
Drawing on the information in the YouTube video transcript, here are the most important points of GeePaw Hill's presentation on Incremental Software Delivery:

\*  \*\*The core argument of the presentation is that you should probably take many more much smaller steps when making changes, particularly when your app is already shipping.\*\* This is presented as a default and powerful piece of advice.

\*  Hill defines a \*\*"step" as a gap in time between two points of "readiness".\*\* At the "before" point, you are ready; during the step, you are unready; and at the "after" point, you are ready again.

\*  \*\*"Ready" means that at any given point, you have source code from which you can regenerate your running app without concerns.\*\* This definition explicitly excludes the requirement that the new program be better than the previous one and also ignores the cost of deployment. The focus is solely on whether deployment would cause a problem.

\*  The traditional approach often involves \*\*very large steps\*\*, potentially lasting weeks or even a month (e.g., 30-day stories).

\*  \*\*Hill argues for a better approach involving many more much smaller changes.\*\* He contends that the trade is deeply invested in the idea that more value comes faster from fewer and larger steps, but \*\*"that's not true".\*\*

\*  The theory of taking fewer and larger steps has \*\*two significant problems\*\*:
  \*  \*\*It does not take into account non-linearity.\*\* Longer steps don't just get bigger in effort linearly; they get "bigger bigger" due to factors like decreased certainty, reduced human mental bandwidth, and increased perturbation.
  \*  \*\*It does not take into account the inherent value in each step.\*\* This value is realized multiple times with smaller steps, whereas it's only captured once in a large step.

\*  \*\*There are three aspects to the inherent value of smaller steps:\*\*
  \*  \*\*Interruptability:\*\* Being in a "ready" state more frequently allows for easier interruption and resumption of work without significant loss of context.
  \*  \*\*Steerability:\*\* Frequent "ready" states enable better responsiveness to changing priorities, market situations, or urgent issues ("brushfires").
  \*  \*\*"Juice" (Dopamine):\*\* Completing smaller steps more often provides regular positive reinforcement and a sense of accomplishment.

\*  When faced with a big story, the first step is to \*\*"turn the ton of fan out of it"\*\* by removing unnecessary features or functionalities that are not immediately required for the core value. It's also crucial to shift the mindset from requiring improvement with every step to simply ensuring the step doesn't make the user's life worse.

\*  Articulating a clear definition of "done" can help in breaking down stories into smaller, manageable increments.

\*  Techniques like releasing new, unused code (e.g., CSS classes or non-accessible code) immediately can further enable smaller, more frequent deployments. This aligns with the principle of \*\*"open for extension closed for modification"\*\*.

\*  The prevailing pedagogy that focuses on greenfield development is misaligned with the reality that most developers work in brownfield environments, emphasizing the need for better teaching of techniques for changing existing code. Keeping methods ridiculously short (e.g., no more than five lines) can naturally lead to smaller, more manageable changes.

\*  The presenter advocates for a \*\*"human local oriented taken and iterative"\*\* approach to change, applicable not just to code but also to individuals, teams, and organizations.

\*  The core message is summarized by the analogies: \*\*"that's too much rice" and "mmm that's not enough garlic"\*\* for software development, which translates to "you should probably take many more much smaller steps then you're taking now".

\*  Overcoming resistance to taking smaller steps often involves \*\*creating experiences\*\* that demonstrate the benefits, rather than relying solely on arguments.
resource: GeePaw Hill on Incremental Software Delivery - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NDXV16uheNs

description: An essential talk to understand how to get the most impact with the least amount of software (and thereby reduce basal cost and time to market). Highly recommended.
name: Make Impacts Not Software
notes:
Success lies in **redefining it from merely delivering software functionalities to achieving measurable business impacts and changes in user behavior**. This entails embracing a dynamic, GPS-like planning method that prioritizes continuous learning, testing assumptions, and adapting to reach the desired destination with the least amount of software possible.

- **Redefine Success as Impact, Not Software:** Shift focus from merely delivering software features or completing user stories to achieving measurable business outcomes (e.g., making/saving money, acquiring customers) and observable changes in user behavior.
- **Embrace Dynamic, GPS-like Planning:** Adopt flexible planning that allows for continuous learning, adaptation, and recalculation of the path, rather than rigid, upfront linear roadmaps.
- **Optimize Delivery for Learning:** Recognize that true understanding of what needs to be delivered emerges through the delivery process itself, requiring plans that anticipate and incorporate learning and change.
- **Focus on Measurable Behavior Changes:** Define project goals in terms of how user or customer behavior will change, making success objectively observable and testable.
- **Unpack and Test Assumptions:** View all software scope as based on assumptions. Visualize these assumptions and actively design experiments to test them quickly and cheaply.
- **Generate Multiple Options:** Create and evaluate several potential solutions or approaches for achieving a desired impact, rather than committing to a single upfront plan.
- **Ask Strategic Questions:** Utilize structured conversations, starting with "Why?" (the ultimate business goal), then "Who?" (the affected users), "How?" (their behavior change), and "What?" (the software to enable that change), to align on objectives.
- **Prioritize Small, Testable Steps:** Break down large goals into small, measurable "next turns" that can be quickly implemented and evaluated to validate the chosen path and assumptions.

description: Legendary builder Bret Taylor offers profound insights on the future of AI agents and their impact on business, the evolving landscape of software development, and critical lessons for product and startup success.
name: He saved OpenAI, invented the “Like” button, and built Google Maps: Bret Taylor (Sierra)
notes:
The talk emphasizes the critical need for **intellectual honesty and relentless self-reflection** to identify the **true, most impactful problems** to solve, rather than defaulting to solutions that align with personal strengths or comfortable assumptions. This involves actively seeking out the actual root causes of issues, even when uncomfortable, and being willing to do what is most impactful for the business, even if it falls outside one's preferred skill set.

**AI and the Future of Software**
- The entire AI market is moving towards **agents and outcomes-based pricing**.
- **Agents are the new app**, becoming the primary product form factor and driving true productivity gains by autonomously accomplishing jobs.
- The act of creating software is transforming from typing code to **operating code-generating machines**.
- **Computer science remains extremely valuable for developing systems thinking**, essential for operating AI code generators and connecting technology with business problems.
- There's a need for a **new programming system designed for AI**, prioritizing verifiability and human leverage over human ergonomics, enabling the creation of robust and complex systems where coding is "free."
- The AI market segments are:
    - **Frontier/Foundation Models:** Dominated by large hyperscalers due to high CapEx; **startups should generally avoid this space**.
    - **Tooling:** Risky due to potential competition from large infrastructure providers moving up the stack.
    - **Applied AI (Agents):** The most significant opportunity for startups, akin to the SaaS market, focusing on building agents for specific business outcomes.
- AI models can serve as **highly effective personalized educational tools**, democratizing access to learning by adapting to individual styles.
- To achieve productivity gains with AI tools, **focus on root cause analysis for incorrect AI outputs and implement AI supervising AI (self-reflection)** to improve robustness.
- AI agents can automate a significant portion of **customer service interactions (50-90%) with high customer satisfaction**.
**Product Strategy**
- The most important lesson in product is to **create entirely new experiences native to the platform**, rather than just digitizing existing solutions or copying competitors.
- Successful products must answer the fundamental question: "**Why should a customer use this thing in the first place?**"
- Product design should focus on **systems that deliver delightful experiences even with messy, uncontrolled real-world data inputs**.
- Adding "sizzle" (like Google Maps' satellite imagery) can generate **viral moments and initial adoption**, complementing the product's core enduring value.
**Business Models & Go-to-Market**
- **Outcome-based pricing is the superior model for AI products**, especially when AI autonomously performs a job with measurable results, aligning vendor and customer incentives.
- **Usage-based pricing (e.g., per token) is often a poor indicator of value** for AI products, as it doesn't necessarily correlate with actual business outcomes.
    - **Choosing the correct go-to-market motion is critical:Developer-led:** For platform products where engineers have buying latitude.
    - **Product-led Growth (PLG):** When the user and buyer are the same person.
    - **Direct Sales:** Increasingly relevant for AI products where the buyer and user are different, and **founders should embrace this approach** even if it's outside their comfort zone.
**Mindset & Leadership**
- Consistently ask: "**What is the most impactful thing I could do today?**" and prioritize tasks based on maximizing impact for the business.
- Cultivate **intellectual honesty and relentless self-reflection** to identify the true, most impactful problems, rather than defaulting to solutions that align with personal strengths or assumptions.
- Be **flexible with your professional identity** and willing to adapt to what the company needs from you at any given time.
- **Seek and listen to advice from external advisors and boards who will tell you what you _need_ to hear**, even if it's uncomfortable.
- When receiving advice, **always ask "why"** to understand the underlying framework and avoid applying anecdotal experiences as universal rules.
- **Develop good judgment** by rigorously reflecting on past decisions and understanding the context of advice.
resource: He saved OpenAI, invented the “Like” button, and built Google Maps: Bret Taylor (Sierra) - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qImgGtnNbx0

name: Building effective engineering teams; lessons from 10 years at Google | Addy Osmani
notes:
Fostering a strong Engineering Culture is the essential foundation for synchronizing Technical Leadership, Management, and Agile practices to optimize Developer Productivity within Teams.... Achieving this alignment ensures that Technology Strategy and Technical Practices work together to drive continuous improvement and successful Product delivery.

- **Engineering Culture** serves as the unifying framework for **Technical Leadership**, **Management**, and the development of **Teams**.
- High-performing organizations prioritize **Developer Productivity** and **Developer Experience (Devex)** to maximize organizational **Flow**.
- The core of technical success involves embedding **Agile**, **XP**, and **DevOps** practices to ensure reliable **Continuous Delivery**.
- **Systems Thinking** and **Team Topologies** are essential for designing organizations that can handle **Scalability** and complex **Architecture**.
- **Technical Practices** must include **Evolutionary Design**, **Software Design**, and **Craftsmanship** to effectively manage **Legacy Code**.
- Success requires aligning **Technology Strategy** with **Product Strategy** through **Lean Startup** and **Product Discovery** principles.
- Continuous improvement is driven by a focus on **Feedback Cycles**, **Testing**, **Refactoring**, and **Observability**.

description: Andrew Ng's talk provides best practices for startups to achieve unprecedented execution speed by leveraging new AI technology for rapid engineering, product iteration, and strategic decision-making
name: Andrew Ng: Building Faster with AI
notes:
A core takeaway from Andrew Ng's talk is that **unprecedented execution speed is paramount for startup success**, a velocity now uniquely enabled by **new AI technology that drastically accelerates engineering and prototyping**. This rapid development, in turn, makes **swift user feedback and precise product iteration** the critical new bottleneck, underscoring the necessity of understanding AI to quickly build products users genuinely love.

- **Execution speed is paramount for startup success**, a velocity now uniquely enabled by **new AI technology that drastically accelerates engineering and prototyping**.
- The **greatest opportunities for startups lie at the application layer** of the AI stack, particularly leveraging the rise of **agentic AI** and its orchestration layer.
- To achieve speed, **focus on concrete, actionable product ideas** that engineers can quickly build and test, avoiding vague concepts.
- **AI coding assistance enables rapid engineering, making prototype development 10x or more faster** and significantly reducing engineering costs, thereby transforming decision-making from "one-way doors" to "two-way doors."
- With engineering accelerating, **product management—specifically getting user feedback and deciding what features to build—becomes the critical new bottleneck**.
- Employ a **portfolio of tactics for obtaining rapid product feedback**, prioritizing quick, iterative cycles (from expert intuition to user testing with strangers) over slower methods like AB testing, and use this data to hone instincts.
- **Deeply understanding AI and its various building blocks** (e.g., prompting, fine-tuning, RAG, evals, guardrails) provides a substantial advantage, enabling teams to combine elements to create novel software.
- **Empower everyone in all job roles to learn to code or effectively steer AI**, as this drastically enhances productivity and commands greater influence over computer outputs.
- The **singular, most important focus for any business is building a product that users genuinely love**, as this foundation outweighs concerns about moats or other factors in early stages.
- Be aware of **AI hype and dangerous narratives**, recognizing that AI's "safety" is a function of its responsible application rather than the technology itself, and resist efforts to centralize control or shut down open-source AI.
resource: Andrew Ng: Building Faster with AI - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RNJCfif1dPY

description: Are you scrambling to meet deadlines only to find more requests piling up in your inbox? Hidden WIP is a major contributor to clogged value streams and overloaded employees, burdened with too many meetings and frustrating work routines. Making work visible highlights the problems leading to low productivity across the organization. In this talk, Dominica shares how to unmask the things that are killing your team’s capacity and their ability to optimize workflow.
name: Making Work Visible: How to Unmask Capacity Killing WIP
notes:
To effectively manage work overload and consistently deliver business value, it is crucial to make all work, including unplanned tasks and dependencies, explicitly visible and to intentionally limit work-in-progress (WIP) to optimize workflow. By doing so, teams can identify bottlenecks, address conflicting priorities, and ensure a smoother flow of activities from start to finish.

- People often take on more work than they can capacity to do, leading to self and team overload, bottlenecks, and delayed business value delivery.
- Reasons for overload include a desire not to let the team down, the appeal of new projects over finishing old ones, underestimating task duration, and difficulty saying no, especially to superiors.
- **Making all work visible** is crucial to unmask capacity-killing overload, including planned, unplanned, and partially completed tasks.
- **Too much Work-In-Progress (WIP)** is the primary deterrent to smooth workflow (FLOW), causing scattered focus, interruptions, context switching, and significantly increasing wait times.
- Visualize and plan for **unplanned work** (emergencies, interruptions) by allocating capacity or creating dedicated visibility lanes, as it will never be eliminated entirely.
- Address **conflicting priorities** by establishing clear prioritization policies and using visual boards to show competing demands, facilitating conversations about what truly is the top priority.
- Expose **dependencies** between tasks, teams, or systems, as these significantly increase the likelihood of delays and contribute to WIP overload.
- **Intentionally limit Work-In-Progress (WIP)** to create a pull system, which gives teams permission to say no to new tasks when capacity is full, ensuring a smoother flow and more predictable delivery of business value.
- Gradually reduce WIP limits over time to find an optimal flow, adjusting them as team capacity changes.
- Leaders must be aware of their positional power, as team members are likely to accept new work even when overloaded, which ultimately hinders the delivery of business value.
resource: Making Work Visible: How to Unmask Capacity Killing WIP - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KR7Y8IUgyyA
